item.title: [Java] Option Argument(s)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

No problem.
Also, if you prefer, you could just try { String reason1 = reason[0]; }
then catch a index out of bounds exception. Lots of different possibilities (enhanced for loop anyone? XD)

Oh yea, and it’s called vargargs, if you want to read up on it

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Option Argument(s)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Well you could do something like:

public void ban(Player name, String ... reason) { if(reason.length > 0) { //yo we haz a reason } else { //no reason bro } }
You can use ban(player) or ban(player, string)

Note: that’s the exact code, … is valid java syntax

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Option Argument(s)
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Kryptix, post:1, topic:395930”]I’ve never come across this in Java before but basically I want a method (for example: ban()) that can have an optional String as an argument.

For example…

ban(Player username, String reason);

ban(Player username);

Is there anyway to do that without having two different methods? I’ve never needed to do this before so I’m not sure what the best approach is.

I suppose with the String reason I could simply handle the reason side of things and then just do ban(Player username) to handle the rest but I’d sooner do it all in one method if possible?[/quote]

I don’t think it’s possible, but you can do something like this:

public void ban(Player player) {
    ban(player, "Some default reason.");
}

public void ban(Player player, String reason) {
    // handle the rest
}

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Option Argument(s)
item.dc:creator: @Kryptix Kryptix
item.description:
@Kryptix wrote:

I’ve never come across this in Java before but basically I want a method (for example: ban()) that can have an optional String as an argument.

For example…

ban(Player username, String reason);

ban(Player username);

Is there anyway to do that without having two different methods? I’ve never needed to do this before so I’m not sure what the best approach is.

I suppose with the String reason I could simply handle the reason side of things and then just do ban(Player username) to handle the rest but I’d sooner do it all in one method if possible?

Read full topic
